Figure 1: Figure 1: Basic Anatomy of a Running Shoe     Running Shoes: Product Guide     Overview     Anatomy of a Running Shoe     Key Components     Upper: The fabric or material covering the top of your foot.•     Midsole: The foam layer providing cushioning and shock absorption.•     Outsole: Durable rubber contacting the ground for traction and durability.•     Heel Counter: Reinforcement in the heel for stability.•     Toe Box: The front part providing space for toes.•     Lacing System: Allows adjustment for a snug �t.•     Product Speci�cationsFeature Typical Value Notes     Weight 230–350g Per shoe, varies by     size/model     Heel Drop 0–12mm Di�erence in height heel-     to-toe     Midsole     Material EVA/PU     Ethylene-vinyl acetate or     polyurethane foam     Outsole Rubber Durable, o�ers traction     Cushioning Light/Medium/Max Depends on intended     usage     Arch Support Neutral/Stability/Motion     Control Match to foot type     Upper     Material Mesh/Synthetic/Knitted     A�ects �t and     breathability     Sizes     Available US 6–14', 'Gel-Kayano 30 Product Page. https://www.asics.com/us/en-us/gel-kayano     [6] HOKA. (2025). Clifton 9 Overview. https://www.hoka.com/en/us/clifton-9/     Care and Maintenance     Clean shoes with mild soap and water, let air dry.•     Avoid machine washing or high heat.•     Replace running shoes every 300–500 miles (480–800 km).•     Store in a cool, dry place.•     Conclusion     References           https://www.runnersworld.com/gear/a20803133/how-to-buy-running-shoes/         https://www.runnersworld.com/gear/a20803133/how-to-buy-running-shoes/         https://www.apma.org/runningshoes         https://www.brooksrunning.com/en_us/ghost-15-mens-running-shoes/110393.html         https://www.brooksrunning.com/en_us/ghost-15-mens-running-shoes/110393.html         https://www.nike.com/running/pegasus         https://www.asics.com/us/en-us/gel-kayano         https://www.hoka.com/en/us/clifton-9/']
response: The weight of running shoes typically ranges from 230 to 350 grams per shoe, though this can vary depending on the size and model. For maintenance, you should clean your running shoes with mild soap and water and let them air dry. Avoid machine washing or exposing them to high heat. It's recommended to replace running shoes every 300 to 500 miles (480 to 800 kilometers) of use. Additionally, you should store them in a cool, dry place.
reference: Clean shoes with mild soap and water, let air dry, void machine washing or high heat, Replace running shoes every 300–500 miles (480–800 km), Store in a cool, dry place.

user_input: How often should I wash the WINTER Jacket?
retrieved_contexts: ["Q: What's the di�erence between CLO rating and temperature rating?     A: CLO rating measures insulation value (thermal resistance). Temperature rating predicts     comfort at speci�c temps based on CLO value, activity level, and wind conditions.     Q: How often should I wash this jacket?     A: Wash when visibly soiled (typically 1-2 times per season for regular users). Excessive     washing reduces DWR e�ectiveness. Use spot cleaning for minor stains.     Q: Can I machine wash or should I hand wash?     A: Both are acceptable. Hand washing is gentler and recommended for best results. Use     cool water, mild detergent, and avoid fabric softener.     Q: How do I know when to reapply DWR coating?     A: When water stops beading on the outer shell. Typically occurs after 20-30 washes or 1-2     seasons of regular use.     Q: Is this jacket waterproof or water-resistant?     A: Water-resistant. The 5,000mm water column rating handles rain and light snow, but     sustained heavy rain may eventually saturate the fabric. For full waterproo�ng in severe     rain, wear over a rain shell.     10.2 Production Standards     10.3 End-of-Life Options     11."]
response: You should wash the winter jacket when it is visibly soiled, which typically occurs 1-2 times per season for regular users. Excessive washing can reduce the DWR (Durable Water Repellent) effectiveness, so it's recommended to use spot cleaning for minor stains between full washes.
reference: Wash when visibly soiled (typically 1-2 times per season for regular users). Excessive washing reduces DWR effectiveness. Use spot cleaning for minor stains.

user_input: What are the key components of the Running Shoes
retrieved_contexts: ['Running shoes are designed to provide comfort, support, and durability for a variety of     running activities. This guide explains key features, provides basic diagrams, and lists     important speci�cations to help users make informed decisions.     Figure 1: Figure 1: Basic Anatomy of a Running Shoe     Running Shoes: Product Guide     Overview     Anatomy of a Running Shoe     Key Components     Upper: The fabric or material covering the top of your foot.•     Midsole: The foam layer providing cushioning and shock absorption.•     Outsole: Durable rubber contacting the ground for traction and durability.•     Heel Counter: Reinforcement in the heel for stability.•     Toe Box: The front part providing space for toes.•     Lacing System: Allows adjustment for a snug �t.•     Product Speci�cationsFeature Typical Value Notes     Weight 230–350g Per shoe, varies by     size/model     Heel Drop 0–12mm Di�erence in height heel-     to-toe     Midsole     Material EVA/PU     Ethylene-vinyl acetate or     polyurethane foam     Outsole Rubber Durable, o�ers traction     Cushioning Light/Medium/Max Depends on intended     usage     Arch Support Neutral/Stability/Motion     Control Match to foot type     Upper     Material Mesh/Synthetic/Knitted     A�ects �t and     breathability     Sizes     Available US 6–14']
response: The key components of running shoes include the upper, which is the fabric or material covering the top of your foot; the midsole, which is the foam layer providing cushioning and shock absorption; the outsole, which is durable rubber that contacts the ground for traction and durability; the heel counter, which provides reinforcement in the heel for stability; the toe box, which is the front part that provides space for toes; and the lacing system, which allows adjustment for a snug fit.
reference: The key components include: Upper: The fabric or material covering the top of your foot, Midsole: The foam layer providing cushioning and shock absorption, Outsole: Durable rubber contacting the ground for traction and durability, Heel Counter: Reinforcement in the heel for stability, Toe Box: The front part providing space for toes, Lacing System: Allows adjustment for a snug fit

response: Yes, there are weight categories for denim jeans. They are classified into four main categories based on weight measured in ounces: Lightweight (5-10 oz) which is breathable and suitable for summer but less durable; Mid-Weight (10-14 oz) which offers optimal durability and is suitable for year-round wear with standard quality; Heavy-Weight (14-18 oz) which provides maximum durability with vintage appeal and warmth; and Extra Heavy (18+ oz) which is premium raw denim used for professional workwear.
